member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Decomposition.Cholesky
member.summary: Computes the Cholesky factorization of a symmetric, positive definite .
member.remarks: Cholesky factorization decomposes symmetric, positive definite matrices. This class does not check whether a matrix is symmetric or not. It only uses the upper triangle of the matrix to compute the decomposition.
The actual decompostiion is not done until one of the class' methods is invoked.

member.summary: Constructs an Cholesky object for the given matrix.
member.param: The matrix to factor.
member.exception: If is not a square matrix.
member.remarks: The actual decompostiion is not done until one of the class' methods is invoked.

member.summary: Return a value indicating whether the matrix is positive definite.
member.returns: true if the matrix is positive definite; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Returns the Cholesky factored matrix (lower triangular form).
member.returns: The lower triangular Cholesky factored matrix.
member.exception: If the matrix is not positive definite.

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Decomposition.Cholesky.Determinant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the matrix.

member.exception: If the matrix is not positive definite.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.StorageFormat
member.summary: Enumeration of the different DenseMatrix Market storage formats.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.StorageFormat.General
member.summary: A standard matrix with no special properties.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.StorageFormat.Symmetric
member.summary: A square, symmetric matrix, matrix[i,j] == matrix[j,i].

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.StorageFormat.Hermitian
member.summary: A square, Hermitian matrix, matrix[i,j] == matrix[j,i].Conjugate.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.StorageFormat.SkewSymmetric
member.summary: A square, skew-symmetric matrix, matrix[i,j] == -matrix[j,i].

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.DataType
member.summary: Enumeration of the different data types DenseMatrix Market files support.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.DataType.Real
member.summary: The matrix is real. DenseMatrix entries are represented by a single double.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.DataType.Integer
member.summary: The matrix has only integer entries. DenseMatrix entries are represented by a single integer.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.DataType.Complex
member.summary: The matrix is complex. DenseMatrix entries are represented by two doubles, the first giving the real part and the second the imaginary part.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.DataType.Pattern
member.summary: Only the matrix nonzero pattern is provided. DenseMatrix entries are omitted (only the nonzero pattern is supplied).

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.ExchangeFormat
member.summary: Enumeration of the DenseMatrix Market exchange formats.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.ExchangeFormat.Array
member.summary: A file format suitable for representing general dense matrices. All entries are provided in a predefined (column oriented) order.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.IO.ExchangeFormat.Coordinate
member.summary: A file format suitable for representing general sparse matrices. Only nonzero entries are provided, and the coordinates of each nonzero entry are given explicitly.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Iterative.BiCgStab
member.summary: A Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Bi-Conjugate Gradient Stabilized (BiCGStab) solver is an 'improvement' of the standard Conjugate Gradient (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the BiCGStab can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The Bi-CGSTAB algorithm was taken from:
Templates for the solution of linear systems: Building blocks for iterative methods
Richard Barrett, Michael Berry, Tony F. Chan, James Demmel, June M. Donato, Jack Dongarra, Victor Eijkhout, Roldan Pozo, Charles Romine and Henk van der Vorst
Url: http://www.netlib.org/templates/Templates.html
Algorithm is described in Chapter 2, section 2.3.8, page 27
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.IIterativeSolver
member.summary: Defines the interface for ISolver classes that solve the matrix equation Ax = b in an iterative manner.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the BiCgStab class.

remarks.para: When using this constructor the solver will use a default preconditioner.

The main advantages of using a user defined are:
It is possible to set the desired convergence limits.
It is possible to check the reason for which the solver finished the iterative procedure by calling the property.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Iterative.CompositeSolver
member.summary: A composite matrix solver. The actual solver is made by a sequence of matrix solvers.

remarks.para:
Solver based on:
Faster PDE-based simulations using robust composite linear solvers
S. Bhowmicka, P. Raghavan a,*, L. McInnes b, B. Norris
Future Generation Computer Systems, Vol 20, 2004, pp 373387
Note that if an iterator is passed to this solver it will be used for all the sub-solvers.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Iterative.GPBiCG
member.summary: A Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient (GPBiCG) solver is an alternative version of the Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the GPBiCG solver can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The GPBiCG algorithm was taken from:
GPBiCG(m,l): A hybrid of BiCGSTAB and GPBiCG methods with efficiency and robustness
S. Fujino
Applied Numerical Mathematics, Volume 41, 2002, pp 107 - 117
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.summary: The status used if there is no status, i.e. the solver hasn't run yet and there is no iterator.

member.summary: The preconditioner that will be used. Can be set to null, in which case the default pre-conditioner will be used.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Iterative.GPBiCG.m_Iterator
member.summary: The iterative process controller.

member.summary: Indicates the number of BiCGStab steps should be taken before switching.

The main advantages of using a user defined are:
It is possible to set the desired convergence limits.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Iterative.MlkBiCgStab
member.summary: A Multiple-Lanczos Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para: The Multiple-Lanczos Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized (ML(k)-BiCGStab) solver is an 'improvement' of the standard BiCgStab solver.

The algorithm was taken from:
ML(k)BiCGSTAB: A BiCGSTAB variant based on multiple Lanczos starting vectors
Man-chung Yeung and Tony F. Chan
SIAM Journal of Scientific Computing
Volume 21, Number 4, pp. 1263 - 1290
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Iterative.TFQMR
member.summary: A Transpose Free Quasi-Minimal Residual (TFQMR) iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The TFQMR algorithm was taken from:
Iterative methods for sparse linear systems.
Yousef Saad
Algorithm is described in Chapter 7, section 7.4.3, page 219
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Preconditioners.Diagonal
member.summary: A diagonal preconditioner. The preconditioner uses the inverse of the matrix diagonal as preconditioning values.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.IPreConditioner
member.summary: The base interface for preconditioner classes.

remarks.para: Preconditioners are used by iterative solvers to improve the convergence speed of the solving process. Note that an increase in convergence speed is related to the number of iterations necessary to get a converged solution. So while in general the use of a preconditioner means that the iterative solver will perform fewer iterations it does not guarantee that the actual solution time decreases given that some preconditioners can be expensive to setup and run.
Note that in general changes to the matrix will invalidate the preconditioner if the changes occur after creating the preconditioner.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Preconditioners.Ilutp
member.summary: This class performs an Incomplete LU factorization with drop tolerance and partial pivoting. The drop tolerance indicates which additional entries will be dropped from the factorized LU matrices.
member.remarks:
The ILUTP-Mem algorithm was taken from:
ILUTP_Mem: a Space-Efficient Incomplete LU Preconditioner
Tzu-Yi Chen, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science,
Pomona College, Claremont CA 91711, USA
Published in:
Lecture Notes in Computer Science
Volume 3046 / 2004
pp. 20 - 28
Algorithm is described in Section 2, page 22

member.summary: The default drop tolerance.

member.summary: The array containing the pivot values.

member.summary: Creates an instance of the Ilutp class with the specified settings.
member.param: The amount of fill that is allowed in the matrix. The value is a fraction of the number of non-zero entries in the original matrix. Values should be positive.

The absolute drop tolerance which indicates below what absolute value an entry will be dropped from the matrix. A drop tolerance of 0.0 means that no values will be dropped. Values should always be positive.
The pivot tolerance which indicates at what level pivoting will take place. A value of 0.0 means that no pivoting will take place.

member.name: P:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Preconditioners.Ilutp.DefaultFillLevel
member.summary: Returns the default fill level.

member.name: P:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Preconditioners.Ilutp.DefaultDropTolerance
member.summary: Returns the default drop tolerance.

member.name: P:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Preconditioners.Ilutp.FillLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of fill that is allowed in the matrix. The value is a fraction of the number of non-zero entries in the original matrix. The standard value is 200.

remarks.para: Values should always be positive and can be higher than 1.0. A value lower than 1.0 means that the eventual preconditioner matrix will have fewer non-zero entries as the original matrix. A value higher than 1.0 means that the eventual preconditioner can have more non-zero values than the original matrix.
Note that any changes to the FillLevel after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: P:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Preconditioners.Ilutp.DropTolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the absolute drop tolerance which indicates below what absolute value an entry will be dropped from the matrix. The standard value is 0.0001.

remarks.para: The values should always be positive and can be larger than 1.0. A low value will keep more small numbers in the preconditioner matrix. A high value will remove more small numbers from the preconditioner matrix.
Note that any changes to the DropTolerance after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: P:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.Preconditioners.Ilutp.PivotTolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the pivot tolerance which indicates at what level pivoting will take place. The standard value is 0.0 which means pivoting will never take place.

remarks.para: The pivot tolerance is used to calculate if pivoting is necessary. Pivoting will take place if any of the values in a row is bigger than the diagonal value of that row divided by the pivot tolerance, i.e. pivoting will take place if row(i,j) > row(i,i) / PivotTolerance for any j that is not equal to i.
Note that any changes to the PivotTolerance after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.remarks: This sort algorithm is used to sort the columns in a sparse matrix based on the value of the element on the diagonal of the matrix.

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.IIterationStopCriterium.DetermineStatus(System.Int32,dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Vector,dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Vector,dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.Vector)
member.summary: Determines the status of the iterative calculation based on the stop criteria stored by the current IIterationStopCriterium.
member.param: The number of iterations that have passed so far.
The vector containing the current solution values.
The right hand side vector.
The vector containing the current residual vectors.
member.returns: An ICalculationStatus which indicates what the status of the iterative calculation is according to the current IIterationStopCriterium.
member.remarks: The individual stop criteria may internally track the progress of the calculation based on the invocation of this method. Therefore this method should only be called if the calculation has moved forwards at least one step.

member.summary: The Householder reflection as a matrix. H = I - ( (2/v^Tv)*(vv^T) where v is Householder.Vector.
member.returns: The reflection matrix.

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.HouseholderTransformation.Transformation
member.summary: The transformation of the original vector. transformation = H*v where H = Householder.Matrix and v is the original vector.
member.returns: The transformed vector.
member.remarks: All elements except the first are zero.

member.summary: The array containing the actual non-zero values. Stored in a compressed row fashion.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.SparseMatrix.mColumnIndices
member.summary: An array containing the column indices of the non-zero values.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.SparseMatrix.mRowIndices
member.summary: The array containing the row indices of the existing rows.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.LinearAlgebra.SparseMatrix.mValueCount
member.summary: The total number of non-zero values in the matrix.
member.remarks: This variable keeps track of the number of non-zero values that are stored in the mValues and mColumnIndices array's. Because of this mValueCount also indicates the 'length' of the array's. Note that the actual arrays may be longer (but never shorter) than indicated by mValueCount. If the actual arrays are longer than indicated reading beyond the number of values (i.e. mValueCount) will produce garbage data.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Math.Precision
member.summary: Utilities for working with floating point numbers.

remarks.para:
Useful links:
http://docs.sun.com/source/806-3568/ncg_goldberg.html#689 - What every computer scientist should know about floating-point arithmetic
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_epsilon - Gives the definition of machine epsilon

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.Math.Precision.s_BinaryBaseNumber
member.summary: The base number for binary values

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.Math.Precision.s_DoublePrecision
member.summary: The number of binary digits used to represent the binary number for a double precision floating point value. i.e. there are this many digits used to represent the actual number, where in a number as: 0.134556 * 10^5 the digits are 0.134556 and the exponent is 5.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.Math.Precision.s_SinglePrecision
member.summary: The number of binary digits used to represent the binary number for a single precision floating point value. i.e. there are this many digits used to represent the actual number, where in a number as: 0.134556 * 10^5 the digits are 0.134556 and the exponent is 5.

member.summary: The maximum relative precision of a double

member.summary: The maximum relative precision of a single

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Math.Precision.EqualsWithTolerance(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int64)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the tolerance or not. Equality comparison is based on the binary representation.

remarks.para: Determines the 'number' of floating point numbers between two values (i.e. the number of discrete steps between the two numbers) and then checks if that is within the specified tolerance. So if a tolerance of 1 is passed then the result will be true only if the two numbers have the same binary representation OR if they are two adjacent numbers that only differ by one step.

The comparison method used is explained in http://www.cygnus-software.com/papers/comparingfloats/comparingfloats.htm . The article at http://www.extremeoptimization.com/resources/Articles/FPDotNetConceptsAndFormats.aspx explains how to transform the C code to .NET enabled code without using pointers and unsafe code.

member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The maximum error in terms of Units in Last Place (ulps), i.e. the maximum number of decimals that may be different. Must be 1 or larger.
member.returns: if both doubles are equal to each other within the specified tolerance; otherwise .

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Math.Precision.EqualsWithinDecimalPlaces(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the specified number of decimal places or not. If the numbers are very close to zero an absolute difference is compared, otherwise the relative difference is compared.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if decimalPlaces == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The number of decimal places.
member.returns: if both doubles are equal to each other within the specified number of decimal places; otherwise .

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Math.Precision.EqualsWithinRelativeDecimalPlaces(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the specified number of decimal places or not.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if decimalPlaces == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The number of decimal places.
member.returns: if both doubles are equal to each other within the specified number of decimal places; otherwise .

member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the specified number of decimal places or not, using the number of decimal places as an absolute measure.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if decimalPlaces == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The number of decimal places.
member.returns: if both doubles are equal to each other within the specified number of decimal places; otherwise .

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Math.Precision.DoubleComparer.Compare(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Compares two double values based on the selected comparison method.
member.param: The first double to compare.
The second double to compare.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared. The return value has the following meanings: Value Meaning Less than zero This object is less than the other parameter. Zero This object is equal to other. Greater than zero This object is greater than other.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Math.SpecialFunctions
member.summary: This class implements a collection of special function evaluations. This class has a static constructor which will precompute a small number of values for faster runtime computations.

member.summary: Static constructor for the special functions class. This method precomputes a small number of values for faster runtime computation.

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Math.SpecialFunctions.GammaLn(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the logarithm of the Gamma function.
member.param: The argument of the gamma function.
member.returns: The logarithm of the gamma function.
member.remarks: This implementation of the computation of the gamma and logarithm of the gamma function follows the derivation in "An Analysis Of The Lanczos Gamma Approximation", Glendon Ralph Pugh, 2004. We use the implementation listed on p. 116 which achieves an accuracy of 16 floating point digits. Although 16 digit accuracy should be sufficient for double values, improving accuracy is possible (see p. 126 in Pugh).

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Math.SpecialFunctions.Gamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the Gamma function.
member.param: The argument of the gamma function.
member.returns: The logarithm of the gamma function.
member.remarks: This implementation of the computation of the gamma and logarithm of the gamma function follows the derivation in "An Analysis Of The Lanczos Gamma Approximation", Glendon Ralph Pugh, 2004. We use the implementation listed on p. 116 which achieves an accuracy of 16 floating point digits. Although 16 digit accuracy should be sufficient for double values, improving accuracy is possible (see p. 126 in Pugh).

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Math.SpecialFunctions.DiGamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the digamma function which is mathematically defined as the derivative of the logarithm of the gamma function. This implementation is based on Jose Bernardo Algorithm AS 103: Psi ( Digamma ) Function, Applied Statistics, Volume 25, Number 3, 1976, pages 315-317. Using the modifications as in Tom Minka's lightspeed toolbox.
member.param: The argument of the digamma function.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.ConwayMaxwellPoisson
member.summary:
The Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution is a generalization of the Poisson, Geometric and Bernoulli distributions. It is parameterized by two real numbers "lambda" and "nu". For nu = 0 the distribution reverts to a Geometric distribution, nu = 1 the distribution reverts to the Poisson distribution, nu -> infinity the distribution converges to a Bernoulli distribution.
This implementation will cache the value of the normalization constant.
member.remarks:
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.
The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: F:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.ConwayMaxwellPoisson.mTolerance
member.summary: Since many properties of the distribution can only be computed approximately, the tolerance level specifies how much error we accept.

member.summary: Caches the value of the normalization constant.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.Gamma
member.summary:
The Gamma distribution is a distribution over the positive real numbers. It is parameterized by a shape parameter a > 0 and an inverse scale parameter b > 0. The pdf is
p(x) = \frac{b^a}{\Gamma(a)} x^{a-1} \exp{-bx}.
member.remarks:
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.
The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.InverseWishart
member.summary: This class implements functionality for the inverse Wishart distribution. This distribution is parameterized by the degrees of freedom nu and the scale matrix S. The inverse Wishart distribution is the conjugate prior for the covariance matrix of a multivariate normal distribution.
member.remarks:
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.
The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.Laplace
member.summary:
The Laplace distribution is a distribution over the real numbers parameterized by a mean and scale parameter. The pdf is
p(x) = \frac{1}{2 * scale} \exp{- |x - mean| / scale}.
member.remarks:
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.
The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.MatrixNormal
member.summary: This class implements functionality for matrix valued normal distributions. The distribution is parameterized by a mean matrix (M), a covariance matrix for the rows (V) and a covariance matrix for the columns (K). If the dimension of M is d-by-m then V is d-by-d and K is m-by-m.
member.remarks:
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.
The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.summary: Constructs a matrix normal distribution with specific mean and covariance matrices.
member.param: The mean of the matrix normal.
The covariance matrix for the rows.
The covariance matrix for the columns.
member.exception: If the dimensions of the mean and two covariance matrices don't match.

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.MatrixNormal.Sample
member.summary: Samples a matrix normal distributed random variable.

member.summary: Samples a matrix normal distributed random variable.
member.param: The random number generator to use.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.Multinomial
member.summary: The multinomial distribution is a distribution over arrays of integers. The distribution is parameterized by a vector of probabilities. In dnAnalytics, the multinomial distribution is parameterized by an array of nonnegative numbers. This array does not need to be normalized (as this is often impossible using floating point arithmetic).
member.remarks:
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.
The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.Multinomial.#ctor(System.Double[])
member.summary: Constructs a multinomial distribution.
member.param: An array of nonnegative ratios: this array does not need to be normalized as this is often impossible using floating point arithmetic.
member.exception: If any of the probabilities are negative or do not sum to one.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.Normal
member.summary:
The Normal distribution is a distribution over the real numbers. The distribution is parameterized by a mean and standard deviation. The pdf is
p(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi} stddev} \exp{-0.5 (x - \mu)^2 / stddev^2}.
member.remarks:
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.
The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Distributions.Wishart
member.summary: This class implements functionality for the Wishart distribution. This distribution is parameterized by the degrees of freedom nu and the scale matrix S. The Wishart distribution is the conjugate prior for the precision (inverse covariance) matrix of the multivariate normal distribution.
member.remarks:
The distribution will use the by default. Users can set the random number generator by using the property.
The statistics classes will check all the incoming parameters whether they are in the allowed range. This might involve heavy computation. Optionally, by setting Control.CheckDistributionParameters to false, all parameter checks can be turned off.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Histogram
member.summary: Computes a histogram of a particular data set. The histogram is represented by bin counts. A datapoint that happens to land on a boundary bin will be put in the larger of the two bins, except if it equals the histogram upper bound.

member.name: M:dnAnalytics.Statistics.Histogram.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a Histogram specifying the number of bins exactly. The upper and lower bound of the histogram will be set to the smallest and larger datapoint.
member.param: The datasequence to build a histogram on.
The number of bins to use.

member.name: T:dnAnalytics.Control
member.summary: Sets parameters for the library.

member.name: P:dnAnalytics.Control.CheckDistributionParameters
member.summary:
If CheckDistributionParameters is set to true, the constructors and static sample methods of the distribution classes will validate each parameter by checking that it is valid. For the multivariate distributions this could involve an expensive matrix factorization.
The default setting of this property is true.

member.name: P:dnAnalytics.Control.ThreadSafeRandomNumberGenerators
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to use thread safe random number generators (RNG). Thread safe RNG about two and half time slower than non-thread safe RNG.
member.value: true to use thread safe random number generators ; otherwise, false.
